docs.title: Source Bundling
docs.description: For detecting mismatches between source code on your local and actual code running on remote applications, Sidekick agent requires source codes to be available in the running application artifact (jar). So source codes should be put into artifacts while building. Otherwise, source code incompatibility checks will not be applied as this is optional. In case of code level conflict is detected between local and remote, put tracepoint request will be rejected.\

docs.title: üè´ Index
docs.description: Sidekick is an open-source Live Application Debugger that helps you to debug issues where they happen, when they happen, without stopping, rebuilding, or redeploying applications. Sidekick agents give you powerful dynamic observability features with near-zero overhead.

docs.title: ‚ùì Why Sidekick?
docs.description: Sidekick helps you quickly and easily modify the collected data to understand the application's behavior in real-time better. This is particularly useful in a live production environment, where it is often necessary to understand and troubleshoot issues quickly and efficiently.

docs.title: Conditional Tracepoints
docs.description: You may need to take snapshots only when certain conditions are met. Use the ‚ÄúCondition‚Äù box in the edit popup to specify an optional condition:

docs.title: Distributed Tracing Integration
docs.description: Sidekick integrates all tracepoints automatically with the rich distributed tracing so that you can see the tracepoint events with all the other actions that your application does end-to-end.

docs.title: Edit Tracepoint
docs.description: It is possible to edit a tracepoint by right-clicking on the tracepoint icon, similar to any arbitrary breakpoint. From this window, it‚Äôs possible to enable or disable the tracepoint, enable or disable distributed tracing (disabled by default), to define the condition for taking snapshots, and to change the default expiration settings of the tracepoint.

docs.title: Enable/Disable Tracepoint
docs.description: When a tracepoint is disabled, it will not be removed but it will stop capturing snapshots. A disabled tracepoint can be enabled back again later till it gets expired. So, disabling a tracepoint is useful when you need to remove it temporarily.

docs.title: Expiration Settings
docs.description: Any tracepoint will expire after certain hit count or time (age) limits are exceeded. When a tracepoint expires, it will be removed automatically. There won't be any tracepoint events for this tracepoint.

docs.title: Connect Source Code
docs.description: It's essential for Sidekick agents to know which branch/code you want to debug. By connecting your source code, you allow Sidekick to understand the correct source code and the correct tracepoint location. Currently, you can import your source code from your GitHub and Gitlab repositories.

docs.title: How to
docs.description: These pages describe the core concepts on how to start using Sidekick for debugging your application. In order to start and get the best out of Sidekick, you need to perform essential actions. In this section, we'll provide the below guides about those actions:

docs.title: üéá Remote Config
docs.description: Remote Config allows us to easily attach and detach Sidekick agents from running applications as well as change agent settings remotely using the Sidekick WebIDE. This can be particularly useful for users with multiple apps with Sidekick agents installed, as it allows us to manage the agents from a central location.

docs.title: Put Tracepoints & Logpoints
docs.description: In order to gather valuable insights from your application, you can start setting tracepoints for your applications. Before setting a tracepoint, make sure that:

docs.title: Take Snapshots (a.k.a Tracepoint Events)
docs.description: After you connect your source code, select applications to debug, and put tracepoints, Sidekick will automatically start taking snapshots, in other words; generating tracepoint events, when the remote application is executed.

docs.title: Enable TraceMap for Debugging
docs.description: Sidekick integrates all tracepoints automatically with the rich distributed tracing so that you can see the tracepoint events with all the other actions that your application does end-to-end.

docs.title: Apps and Sidekick Actions Panels
docs.description: In order to start debugging with Sidekick, one of the pre-requisites is to install Sidekick agent into your app and select it on the Sidekick dashboard. Apps and tracepoints panel let developers manage their Sidekick agent installed applications and tracepoints set on those applications.

docs.title: Code Panel
docs.description: After you connect your code, you can open any file that you'd like to view or debug to the code panel. Sidekick lets you put tracepoints for the application code.

docs.title: Events Panel
docs.description: After you put a tracepoint and execute the code, Sidekick will take a snapshot of the application. You will be able to see the list and the details of snapshot events taken by the Sidekick on the Events panel.

docs.title: Introduction to Web Application
docs.description: This guide explains the components of Sidekick's Web Application.

docs.title: Sources Panel
docs.description: It's essential for Sidekick agents to know which branch/code you want to debug. By connecting your source code, you allow Sidekick to understand the correct source code and the correct tracepoint location.

docs.title: üèÉ‚ôÄ Quick Start: To-Do App
docs.description: Option 1: Sandbox

docs.title: Browsing Tracepoint Events
docs.description: After your application triggered on line that is put tracepoint, you can see incoming events by clicking tracepoint or opening Sidekick Panel.

docs.title: Common Problems
docs.description: * Safari login issues: We are working on this issue. Until then you can try changing your default browser to Mozilla Firefox or Google Chrome.

docs.title: Login & On-boarding
docs.description: This guide explains how to log in to your Sidekick account on Visual Studio Code.

frontMatter.description: This guide explains how to log in to your Sidekick account on Visual Studio Code.

docs.title: Visual Studio Code Extension (Python & Node.js)
docs.description: Sidekick VSCode extension enables developers to debug applications remotely from the comfort of their IDE. With this plugin, developers can build faster by resolving the issues in pre-production & production using real data.

docs.title: Select Workspace & Application
docs.description: Sidekick allows you to have more than one workspace so that you can seperate your apps for different contexts or environments.

docs.title: Self-hosted Settings
docs.description: You need to change your broker host and port at the Sidekick settings.

docs.title: Set up VSCode extension
docs.description: You can download our extension and participate in our public beta through VSCode Marketplace.

docs.title: Conditional tracepoints
docs.description: You may need to take snapshots only when certain conditions are met. Use the ‚ÄúCondition‚Äù box in the edit popup to specify an optional condition:

docs.title: Edit Tracepoint
docs.description: You can edit your tracepoints by clicking on the Pen icon next to each tracepoint under the Tracepoints panel.

docs.title: Enable/Disable Tracepoint
docs.description: When a tracepoint is disabled, it will not be removed but it will stop capturing snapshots. A disabled tracepoint can be enabled back again later till it gets expired. So, disabling a tracepoint is useful when you need to remove it temporarily.

docs.title: Expiration Settings
docs.description: Any tracepoint will expire after certain hit count or time (age) limits are exceeded. When a tracepoint expires, it will be removed automatically. There won't be any tracepoint events for this tracepoint.

docs.title: Tracepoints & Logpoints
docs.description: When you put a tracepoint on a line, the Sidekick agent on the corresponding remote application takes a snapshot of the local variables on that point when the execution passes from that point and sends them as tracepoint snapshot events back to your VSCode instance.

docs.title: Remove Tracepoint
docs.description: You can delete your tracepoints by clicking on the Bin icon next to each tracepoint under the Tracepoints panel.

docs.title: Set Tracepoint
docs.description: Setting up a tracepoint helps developers understand code execution on specific parts of an application. It‚Äôs as easy as setting up an ordinary line breakpoint with just one right-click on the desired line and selecting the Add Tracepoint button under the Sidekick section.

docs.title: WebStorm Plugin (Node.js)
docs.description: Sidekick WebStorm Plugin enables developers to debug their Node.js applications remotely from the comfort of their IDE. With this plugin, developers can build faster by resolving the issues in production & pre-production better.

docs.title: üßëüè´ Index
docs.description: Sidekick is an open-source Live Application Debugger that helps you to debug issues where they happen, when they happen, without stopping, rebuilding, or redeploying applications. Sidekick agents give you powerful dynamic observability features with near-zero overhead.

docs.title: Conditional Expressions
docs.description: You may need to take snapshots only when certain conditions are met. Use the ‚ÄúCondition‚Äù box in the edit popup to specify an optional condition:

docs.title: ‚Åâ FAQ
docs.description: What does a Tracepoint mean?

docs.title: Logpoint Expressions
docs.description: Sidekick Logpoint expressions are based on \{{ mustache \}}. You can get detailed information about the mustache library from here//mustache.github.io/mustache.5.html

docs.title: üö® Error Stack Collection
docs.description: Automatic error stack collection is a feature of Sidekick that allows you to automatically collect the stack trace of an error as it occurs without requiring manual intervention. This can be a valuable tool for debugging and troubleshooting issues in an application, as it provides a detailed record of the application's execution at the time of the error, which can help you understand what caused the error and how to fix it.

docs.title: ü™µ Logpoint
docs.description: Logpoints bring the power of dynamic logging to Sidekick users. Replacing traditional logging with dynamic logging has potential to lower stage sizes, costs and time for log searching while giving ability to add new logpoints without editing the source code, redeploying or restarting the application.

docs.title: üíæ Reference Events & Probe Tags
docs.description: Sidekick allows you to save reference stack events,  compare stacks, and control multiple logpoints and tracepoints using tags.

docs.title: üîé Tracepoint
docs.description: Non-breaking breakpoints that bring the ease of local debugging to production!

frontMatter.description: Non-breaking breakpoints that bring the ease of local debugging to production!

docs.title: Table of contents
docs.description: * üßëüè´ Index

docs.title: Conditional Stack & Log Collection
docs.description: Conditional stack and log collection is a debugging technique that allows you to selectively collect stack traces and log messages based on specified conditions. This can be useful in various situations, such as when you are trying to troubleshoot an issue in a live production environment or when you want to optimize the performance of your application.

next.title: Cut Monitoring Costs with Dynamic Logging

docs.title: Cut Monitoring Costs with Dynamic Logging
docs.description: Dynamic logging with logpoints is a debugging technique that allows you to modify an application's log output while running without requiring a restart. This can be useful for debugging and troubleshooting issues in a live production environment. It allows developers to quickly and easily add or modify log statements in the application to collect more detailed information about its behavior.

docs.title: Developer on-boarding
docs.description: Logpoints and tracepoints are features of live application debuggers that can be particularly useful for onboarding new developers.

previous.title: Cut Monitoring Costs with Dynamic Logging

docs.title: Dynamic Logging
docs.description: Dynamic logging refers to modifying an application's log output while running without requiring a restart. This can be useful for debugging and troubleshooting issues in a live production environment. It allows developers to quickly and easily add or modify log statements in the application to collect more detailed information about its behavior.

next.title: Error stack collection & stack-based backend tests in E2E tests

docs.title: Error stack collection & stack-based backend tests in E2E tests
docs.description: E2E tests ensure that the application performs as expected by running the test cases based on user workflows. Tools such as Cypress, Playwright & Selenium enable us to define and apply those tests easily.

docs.title: Identifying Stack Changes & Stack Comparison
docs.description: Identifying stack changes and stack comparison is a debugging technique that involves comparing the stack traces of two different executions of an application to understand how the application's behavior has changed. This can be useful in various situations, such as when you are trying to troubleshoot an issue in a live production environment or trying to understand how changes to the application's code have affected its behavior.

previous.title: Error stack collection & stack-based backend tests in E2E tests

docs.title: Pinpointing Causes of Errors
docs.description: Pinpointing the cause of errors is a common task when debugging an application, and tracepoints can be helpful for this purpose.

docs.title: Production Debugging
docs.description: Production debugging refers to identifying and fixing issues that occur in a production environment, which is the environment where a software application or system is deployed and used by real users. Production debugging can be challenging, as it involves diagnosing and fixing problems that may not have been identified during the development or testing phases of the software.

next.title: Remote Debugging Kubernetes Cluster, Pods, and Containers

docs.title: ü•û Use Cases
docs.description: Sidekick comes with many different features. It is not limited to the ones we offer.

docs.title: Remote Debugging Kubernetes Cluster, Pods, and Containers
docs.description: In the context of live application debugging, remote debugging refers to the practice of debugging an application that runs on a remote machine rather than on the local machine where the debugger is running. This can be particularly useful when the application runs in a Kubernetes cluster, as it allows developers to troubleshoot and fix issues without setting up a local development environment or manually deploying the application to their local machine.

next.title: Using Trace Data to Find Root Cause of an Error

docs.title: Using Trace Data to Find Root Cause of an Error
docs.description: Trace data refer to the detailed information that is collected about the execution of an application. This data can help debug and troubleshoot issues in an application, as it provides a detailed record of what the application was doing at different points in time.

previous.title: Remote Debugging Kubernetes Cluster, Pods, and Containers
